parts: Name this island nation which was ruled by two different members of the Duvalier family.
Papa Doc Duvalier's government employed this fearsome secret police force, who took their name from a mythological figure who stole children
This figure was elected to the presidency of Haiti in 1990, only to be deposed in 1991. He was elected again in 2004, only to once again be overthrown and exiled.
Name this prototypical antibiotic, which prevents the formation of bacterial cell walls. It revolutionized the treatment of infectious disease, but is rarely used anymore due to resistance.
Bacterial cell walls are primarily composed of this substance, which is a polymer of N-acetyl-glucosamine and N-acetyl-muramic acid. It also contains D-amino acids.
In Gram-negative bacteria, enzymes that cleave beta-lactams can be found in this compartment, which is located between the inner and outer membranes.
Name this realist play in which Nina spurns the love of that play-within-a-playwright and rejects a gift from him in favor of leaving for Eltz with an acclaimed novelist.
This Russian wrote of Konstantin Treplyov shooting the title bird and himself in The Seagull. His other realistic dramas include The Three Sisters and The Cherry Orchard.

The incredibly influential Moscow Art Theater production of The Seagull was co-directed by Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko and this man, who developed a namesake system of theater praxis in which emotions are produced through specific physical actions.
Identify these circuit components which store energy in an electric field. The parallel-plate variety is commonly used to illustrate their properties

These nonconducting materials are often sandwiched in between the plates of a parallel plate capacitor in order to increase their capacitance. They will conduct electricity above the breakdown voltage.

This type of cable, which acts as a capacitor, consists of a central wire surrounded by a dielectric material, which is in turn surrounded by an outer conducting sheath. They are used to transmit radio signals.
Give this term for any process by which soil and rock move downhill under the force of gravity. Creep is a particularly slow example.
This particular type of landslide is a sudden rapid flow of snow down a slope, and can be triggered by rockfall and sudden impacts.
When granular material accumulates, it forms a conical hill. The angle of the hill relative to the horizontal is given this name.
Many tribes in the area make cedar tree trunks into these structures with ancestors, animals, and events carved into the wood.

] In this elaborate multi-feast procedure, hosts provide food and ritually disburse gifts to enhance their own prestige. Banned by Canada for many years, it is practiced by tribes such as the Tlingit.

Plains peoples like the Lakota practice this other ceremony, which relies on heated stones placed inside the namesake structure. Its legal status became contentious after self-help con man James A. Ray killed two disciples in 2009 while attempting to co-opt this ceremony into New Age nonsense.
Identify this British royal building at Whitehall erected in 1622 whose facade places four sets of Ionic and Corinthian columns within two sets of pilasters on the outer bays.

The Banqueting House at Whitehall is one of the few surviving buildings designed by this architect, who was heavily influenced by Andrea Palladio. His rectangular design for Covent Garden was inspired by the Place Royale in Paris

This other British architect worked with men like Robert Hooke to construct several buildings in the aftermath of the Great Fire of London. He's best known for constructing the new St. Paul's Cathedral.

Name this man whose mentor was Saint Paul. He is the namesake of two pastoral epistles written by Paul, the first of which includes the famous verse "for the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil."
2 Timothy mentions Jannes and Jambres, sorcerers who opposed this biblical figure who turned a staff into a snake and led the Israelites out of Egypt.
In an earlier epistle, Paul attempted to effect a reconciliation between Philemon and Onesimus, who had this relationship with one another.
] Name this woman who marries Will and sets out to change the town of Gopher Prairie, Minnesota in the novel Main Street.
] Main Street, like Babbitt, Arrowsmith, and less popular novels like Mantrap and The Man Who Knew Coolidge, was written by this Minnesotan author
] Babbitt is set in Zenith, which is the biggest city in this fictional state. This fictional state is also the setting of Dodsworth, Arrowsmith, and Gideon Planish
0] Name this construct, which in its familiar form involves the combination of a thesis and antithesis into a synthesis
This philosopher popularized the above dialectical method, which is often named for him. He described Sittlichkeit, or "ethical order," in his Phenomenology of Mind.
This Frankfurt School philosopher wrote Negative Dialectics and described the "culture industry" along with Max Horkheimer in Dialectic of Enlightenment
Name this technique which probes vibrational transitions in molecules using light with a wavelength longer than visible light
This functional group has a sharp peak around 1700 inverse centimeters. This functional group contains a carbon double bonded to an oxygen in the middle of a carbon chain

Ahmed Zewail developed this branch of chemistry, which uses ultrafast laser pulses to observe reaction kinetics on short timescales. It is named for the fact that it can observe reactions on the order of 10 to the negative 15 seconds
] Name this Chief of Staff of the Prussian Army, who defeated Ludwig von Benedek at the Battle of Koniggratz to start the Austro-Prussian War
Helmut von Moltke also led the Prussians through this conflict fought over Alsace-Lorraine, which included the Siege of Metz and a battle in which Patrice McMahon was wounded, the Battle of Sedan.

] The Franco-Prussian war was ended by this treaty, which installed Wilhelm I of Prussia as German emperor and gave the inhabitants of Alsace-Lorraine the choice between becoming German citizens or leaving
Name this totalitarian state founded in a coup led by the Sons of Jacob, in which select women, such as Offred ("of"-Fred), are forced to serve as concubines for couples with low fertility rates
Gilead is the setting for this dystopian novel by Margaret Atwood
The Commander invites Offred to meet him in secret in order to engage in this activity, one of many intellectual pursuits forbidden to women, and rewards her for doing so with magazines and lotion.
This popular user-edited website, founded by Jimbo Wales, went offline for a day to protest the Stop Online Piracy Act.
The Pirate Party International was founded by activists in this European country and won two seats to its Parliament in 2009. Servers in this country host The Pirate Bay.
This Megaupload owner was recently arrested in his lavish New Zealand mansion. He had earlier been prosecuted for insider trading charges relating to the LetsBuyIt website.
Name this eccentric French composer who often used no bar lines in his works, and depicted ancient Greece in his three Gymnopedies.

Satie composed seven piano pieces with this name, which he coined. They include odd instructions such as "arm yourself with clairvoyance," and the first of them is characterized by many Eastern-sounding grace notes
A performance of Satie's Vexations, in which the same piece is played 840 straight times, inspired this American composer to write 4' 33"
Name this patron of Alcuin and Einhard. This Holy Roman Emperor's general Roland was defeated by Basques at the Battle of Roncevaux Pass
This pope consecrated Charlemagne's Palatine Chapel at Aachen after fleeing Roman threats. He later crowned Charlemagne as Emperor of the Romans at St. Peter's Basilica on Christmas Day
Leo's coronation of Charlemagne angered this Byzantine empress, who sought to marry him. She was exiled to Lesbos following a coup by Nikephoros I that ended the Isaurian Dynasty
0] These figures, whose names are Brontes, Steropes, and Arges, are depicted making thunderbolts for Zeus
This figure is depicted in a chariot race for Hippodamia's hand in marriage. This son of Tantalus had earlier been given an ivory shoulder to replace the one Demeter ate.
Two brothers are depicted with their greatest construction, the walls of Thebes. One moved the stones, and the other played his lyre to induce them to form the wall. Name either.
Name this type of fourteen-line poem. English and Spenserian ones are generally structured as three quatrains and a concluding couplet.

This Elizabethan poet wrote one of the first English sonnet sequences, Astrophil and Stella. He also wrote a prose romance in which the king Basilius and his queen Gynecia both fall in love with the disguised Pyrocles in the title location, Arcadia.

] In this work, Sidney claims that literature "nothing affirms, and therefore never lieth," and argues that the title discipline is a better teacher than philosophy and history because it both delights and instructs
Identify this organ, which uses sac-like terminals called alveoli to exchange atmospheric gases with the bloodstream

This substance is secreted by type II pneumocytes in the alveolus, and is responsible for preventing alveoli from collapsing during respiration. Its primary component is DPPC and it works by decreasing surface tension
Premature infants are unable to secrete enough surfactant unless this hormone is given to the mother during labor. This hormone is overproduced in Cushing's syndrome.
What entrepreneur and railroad magnate outmaneuvered Daniel Drew in the steamboat business, but lost millions in the Erie War against Jay Gould and James Fisk?

Vanderbilt fiercely opposed this American filibuster, who interfered with the railroad business in Nicaragua. He declared himself president of the Republic of Lower California and Republic of Sonora, before being executed in Honduras.
Early in his career, Vanderbilt worked under this ferry entrepreneur, helping him break the steamboat monopoly of Fulton and Livingston.
0] Identify this painting, abandoned in 1792, that would have depicted over 630 men swearing the title allegiance
The Tennis Court Oath is an unfinished drawing by this artist, better known for Neoclassical paintings like The Death of Socrates and The Oath of the Horatii.
] David first showed his version of the "Intervention" of these people in front of a large mirror. Giambologna and Nicolas Poussin created works where these classical figures are being abducted

Identify this story in which the brothel owner Mother Shipton and the gambler John Oakhurst sacrifice themselves, but are unable to prevent the Duchess and Piney Woods from dying together in a cabin after a snowstorm.
"The Outcasts of Poker Flat" was written by this editor of the Overland Monthly, a California-based author whose other famous stories include "The Luck of Roaring Camp".

This Harte poem, a parody of Algernon Swinburne's "Atalanta in Calydon", was written to satirize Irish prejudice against Chinese immigrants and features Ah Sin, who cheats at euchre. Unfortunately, most of its audience missed the satire, and Harte later disowned it.
Name these celebrations of military victories in ancient Rome.
] During a triumph, the celebrated general used the picta version of this traditional Roman object
This Numidian was strangled in jail following the 104 BCE triumph of his nemesis.
